Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

Jonathan Perrinet Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain , Xabiel G. Pañeda Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain , Sergio Cabrero Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain , David Melendi Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain Correspondencemelendi@uniovi.es
, Roberto García Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain & Víctor García Department of Informatics , University of Oviedo , Asturies, Spain
Pages 703-728
Published online: 04 Mar 2011
  • Download citation
In this articleClose

            Articles

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            • Full Article
            • Figures & data
            • References

            • Metrics

            • PDF

            Abstract

            The development of the technologies behind Interactive Digital Television (IDTV) services has produced a new type of audience. Traditional viewers now become users as they may play an active role in front of the TV, for example, by choosing a video to be played on demand or by introducing text on an IDTV application. In these services, interactions need to be performed with a remote control, currently the main interaction device, or other devices such as keyboards or mice, which are not very popular in this environment. Nevertheless, although remote controls are essential tools for IDTV services, they are very limited when it comes to writing text. Thus, this study evaluated different alternatives to introduce text on an IDTV application with a remote control. A heterogeneous group of people was selected to write predefined sentences in Spanish in a test environment using three virtual keyboard layouts and the multitap mechanism. Their performance and subjective impressions reveal weaknesses and strengths of the evaluated methods. The article draws important conclusions about the usage of remote controls in IDTV applications, not only for the design of new applications but also for the research of new techniques to introduce text.

            1. INTRODUCTION

            The advantages of digital TV over analogue systems are widely known. Not only do users benefit from this technology with better quality and a greater variety of channels on offer but broadcasters are able to provide additional services that go beyond TV.

            A few years ago, digital contents were mainly provided by private satellite or cable companies. They attracted new clients by offering better quality, better contents, and more channels but not more services. Because there were only a few providers, we can say that there was not much competition in the digital TV market. Recently, this situation has changed drastically with the promotion of Digital Terrestrial Television and new standards for digital TV, like DVB. In the European Union, according to government regulations, countries must switch from analogue to digital television before 2012 (European Union, 2005). Furthermore, analogue terrestrial TV switch-off has already taken place in some European countries such as the Netherlands or Finland, and it will take place at the end of 2010 or earlier in other countries such as Denmark or Spain. In the United States, the Congress mandated June 12, 2009 (extended from February 17, 2009) as the last day for full-power television stations in the United States to broadcast in analogue (Congressional Record, 2009). According to U.S. Federal Communications Commission reports, since June 13, 2009, all full-power U.S. TV stations have been transmitting in digital only. These regulation changes have created a new scenario: a large market and an enormous supply, thus, more competition, encouraging content providers to offer advanced services to be competitive.

            Most of these advanced services require interaction capabilities, but traditionally, television has been a one-way communication channel limiting the actions that viewers could perform. Technical constraints were one powerful reason behind these limitations because there was no feasible way to transmit user messages back to the service provider. In other words, there was no adequate return channel. Sometimes telephone lines were used for this purpose, but for very simple actions such as buying access to a particular channel or program. However, they were expensive and inefficient for an intensive use. The proliferation of home Internet connections and the general evolution of telecommunication networks have changed this scenario. Internet and TV have merged, forming services such as IPTV or Internet TV. In addition, new set-top-box devices allow users to receive TV and connect to the Internet at the same time, making interactive digital television (IDTV) possible and, thus, allowing content providers to offer the aforementioned advanced services.

            For these reasons, there has been a small increase in new services associated to TV channels. Some of these services only offer additional personalized information, such as latest news, stock market reports, or sports results, and they rarely require the introduction of text. However, some others may be much more complex. This can be the case of interactive games, surveys, or t-learning environments. They can include many elements such as text, pictures, sound, or video. In addition, the level of interaction may be much higher. For example, the user may have to control objects on the screen (games) or write text such as a username, a password, a message, and so forth.

            Although the technologies behind IDTV services have evolved greatly, if complex applications are to be developed we also have to design effective methods of user interaction. In this environment, interactions cannot be very complex, as the main interaction device available is the remote control. This is a problem when it comes to text introduction, as remote controls have not been designed for this purpose. External keyboards are available for some devices, but they are not very popular and their design does not make them comfortable to use from an armchair. Thus, if we need the users to introduce text on IDTV applications, we have to answer questions such as, what are the methods available for text introduction with a remote control, how are the users familiarized with each of these methods, how does experience or age (Taveira & Choi, 2009) influence the effectiveness of these methods, and which is the best method available for text introduction with a remote control?

            These questions are addressed in this article. We have evaluated four different methods of text introduction for IDTV applications. A heterogeneous group of people was selected for the evaluation—people with different ages, genders, and backgrounds. Our aim is to determine which is the most efficient and favorite method. The results show that the choice of a text input method is critical for some users. There are only a few studies about text introduction on TV environments and even fewer with results obtained from real users. Thus, this article advances on human interaction in these environments, and its results are very interesting for researchers and designers of IDTV applications.

            The rest of the article is organized as follows. In section 1.1, we comment on previous works with reviews and experiments of text input methods. In section 2, we present our evaluation method and its characteristics. The evaluation and the obtained results are detailed in section 3. Finally, conclusions and future work are presented in section 4.

            1.1. Related Work

            The study and the comparison of text input methods is a field that has generated a lot of research. Nevertheless, to our knowledge, the most recent review points out that almost all this research concerns mobile devices such as personal digital assistants (PDAs; with or without stylus), touch screens, or mobile phones (MacKenzie & Soukoreff, 2002). Although some results may be reused for IDTV, there are several issues to consider. First, users interact with a remote control and not with a keyboard, stylus, or touch screen. Second, the keys and the screen are in different devices, thus users cannot look at the interaction device and the screen at the same time. With the arrival of IDTV, text input methods have become a new challenge.

            In the area of mobile devices there are several studies about virtual keyboards. Bellman and MacKenzie (1998) compared two types of virtual keyboards. The first was the well-known QWERTY, and the second was an optimized layout called Fluctuating Optimal Character Layout (FOCL). The FOCL method consists in changing the position of the letters of the keyboard so that letters most likely after a selected letter are set closest to it. To compare these two methods, the authors conducted a within-subjects design experiment with 11 subjects; the majority were students of the authors' university. Each participant had to write phrases with the two methods during 10 sessions of 15 min. Sentences were selected from various Internet articles. The results show that there were no significant differences between both methods and that participants were not able to scan optimally FOCL keyboards.

            Zhai, Hunter, and Smith (2000) presented a new virtual keyboard layout. According to them, existing keyboard layouts, and more specifically the QWERTY layout, are intended to be used with two hands and so are not appropriate for devices such as PDAs, mobile phones, or tablet computers. To increase the writing speed in these devices, a new layout called Metropolis was developed that is 40% faster than the QWERTY layout. Brewbaker (2008) pursued the same goal using another method based on a genetic algorithm that allowed him to customize the dimension and the language of the keyboard. The obtained results are similar to those of Zhai et al. (2000). Unfortunately, these two layouts were not tested with real users. Thus, it is unknown whether they will satisfy real users despite the fact that they are faster.

            Apart from virtual keyboards, there are other mobile text input methods that have been studied in previous works. Silfverberg, MacKenzie, and Korhonen (2000) compared three text input techniques on mobile phones: multipress (with and without timeout), two keys, and T9. The evaluation was conducted with 12 volunteers aged 23 to 47, almost all of whom were regular mobile phone users. Results highlight better performances by the T9 input method. MacKenzie, Kober, Smith, Jones, and Skepner (2001) tested another mobile text input disambiguation technique based on prefixes probabilities: LetterWise. This technique aims to help users providing disambiguation using a database of probabilities of prefixes instead of a dictionary disambiguation like T9. To compare these two methods, they performed a 20-participant between-subjects evaluation. Participants were paid, and they performed 20 sessions of about 25 to 30 min each where they had to enter phrases from a set prepared by the authors. Entry speeds were similar in the first session, but the last session showed a significant difference between them. Nevertheless, they could not establish a significant difference between error rates. MacKenzie and Tanaka-Ishii (2007a) presented different organizations of keyboards and telephone keypads, and various methods of disambiguation. They showed the characteristic measures for ambiguous telephone keyboards, and they explained how to evaluate a keyboard using the number of keystrokes per character and per word, developing a model. Also, they presented some results of the evaluation of the different keyboards.

            Still in the field of mobile devices, other techniques called concurrent techniques aim to combine two methods simultaneously. Although there are several studies of this kind, the results of Widgor and Balakrishnan (2004) are particularly remarkable. They performed a comparative study on the improvement of writing speed when using this kind of techniques. In this case, they added three extra keys to a classic mobile phone, and users had to combine them with a numeric key to write a letter or a number. The experiment they conducted with 15 users familiar with mobile phones showed a significant improvement of performance. Also, Oniszczak and MacKenzie (2004) presented a new technique called “RollPad.” It is a 12-key soft keypad where each key pressure is combined with roll movements. For example, to type “a,” the user has to press key number 2 and move the finger to the left. They compare this technique with the traditional multitab method in an experiment with 14 participants aged 18 to 35. Although the results do not show any significant difference for entry speeds and error rates, the number of keystrokes per character with RollPad is significantly lower requiring less physical effort, whereas the cognitive load is higher (because there is no difference between speeds).

            Before the year 2006 few studies dealt with the interactive television case and the usage of remote controls for text introduction, as stated in Iatrino and Modeo (2006). To our knowledge, this situation has continued from that year on.

            Remote controls can be used with two possible ways of text introduction: using the arrows and the ok keys, or using number keys like in mobile phones. Iatrino and Modeo (2006) evaluated both ways by performing a within-group design experiment. Three methods were tested: the multipress method (like in a mobile phone), the multipress method with visual feedback, and a virtual keyboard (in this case, with a QWERTY layout). Thirty-six subjects participated in their experiment, and they had to solve two tasks with each method. The first task consists in writing an e-mail address, and the second involved writing a short sentence in Italian. The conclusions highlight several key localization problems, and the multipress method appeared to be the best one.

            In Ingmarsson, Dinka, and Zhai (2004), the authors experiment a new text entry technique called TNT. The system is based on a 3 × 3 grid of nine cells with each cell subdivided into nine smaller cells. Each of the smallest cells has one character, making a total of 81 possible characters. To introduce a character, the user has to select one of the main cells using the numeric keyboard of the remote control and then select the character using the remote again. As we can see, every character of the grid is accessible with only two movements. Five paid subjects, aged 27 to 32, tested the system during 10 sessions of 45 min in order to write a novel in Swedish. The results show writing speeds comparable or superior to PDA handwriting or multitap methods. The subjects found the method easy to use and understand.

            More recently, Geleijnse, Aliakseyeu, and Sarroukh (2009) compared three remote control (RC) techniques (multitap, T9, and an on-screen virtual keyboard layout) and two using a standard QWERTY keyboard (with and without auto-completion). The goal of the experiment was to find videos in YouTube by introducing a pair “artist-track” using each one of these methods. The evaluation was based on the answers of 22 participants, aged 21 to 32, to the HED/UT questionnaire and their time to complete the task. Despite the fact that the authors did not specify the attitudes of the users toward technology, it is not surprising to see that results show a significant difference between RC techniques and the physical keyboard using smart text entry. What it is certainly surprising is that the authors did not find any significant difference between RC techniques. They also concluded that, under the conditions of the experiment, “user tests have not shown any indications that users do not accept the keyboard in a living room-like setting. (p. 148)”

            This conclusion contrasts with those of Orbist, Bernhaupt, and Tscheligi (2008), who advocated systems based on voice. The results of their ethnographic study indicate that it is unrealistic to rely on the popularity of television external devices.

            As can be seen, there are not many studies that deal with the television case. Many publications report conclusions based on Fitt's model predictions (MacKenzie, 1991). Others rely on not very extended techniques such as external keyboards or voice recognition. Others perform evaluations with real people, but a homogeneous group of subjects is chosen: commonly expert and young.

            The main contributions of our article are as follows: The results have been obtained from an experiment that was conducted with a heterogeneous set of real users: nonexpert and expert, young and old, male and female. These participants come from a different cultural environment than users from other experiments in previous works, so the results may be compared allowing us to know whether they can be extrapolated globally or not. Moreover, four text entry methods were tested in order to compare the two ways of writing of the remote control (three are based on virtual keyboard layouts, and one is based on the mobile phone technique: multitap). Furthermore, two of these methods have scarcely been analyzed in previous works (Genetic and Square Alphabetic). Also, a suggestion mechanism has been designed in order to improve the efficiency of the evaluated methods. Finally, the experiment is longer than experiments in previous works: Users had to perform the tests in five sessions, so the changing rate of learning of each method has also been analyzed.

            2. METHOD

            2.1. Goals

            The goal of this study is to determine two elements: efficiency and user preference. For this purpose, a set of users needs to be chosen to write several texts with different methods in order to gather the following information:

            •

            Entry speed: in words per minute

            •

            Error rate: percentage of mistaken characters written

            •

            User satisfaction: subjective impression of the user

            •

            Changing rate of learning: improvement of the previous indicators

            As efficiency and user preference may vary depending on aspects such as age, experience, gender, and so on, a heterogeneous group of users needs to be chosen. Also, to obtain context-independent conclusions, general texts need to be used, for example, texts from newspapers. Finally, to evaluate the changing rate of learning and to avoid first-impression results, the experiments need to be performed in different sessions.

            2.2. Input Methods

            As mentioned in section 1.1, remote controls can be used with two possible methods of text introduction: using the arrow and ok keys over a keyboard layout, or using number keys like in mobile phones. We have evaluated four methods of text input: Three of them are based on keyboard layouts, and one is the popular multitap mobile phone method. The keyboard layouts selected are QWERTY, as it is the most popular nowadays; Square Alphabetic (Zhai, Hunter, & Smith, 2002), as its order is already known by nonexpert users who would find it very easy to use; and a Genetic keyboard designed according to Brewbaker (2008). The multitap method has been selected because it is well known by the “mobile phone generation,” and previous works show that it is more efficient than virtual keyboards in IDTV environments (Iatrino & Modeo, 2006).

            Virtual keyboards

            Three of the text input methods evaluated consist of three different virtual keyboard layouts described as follows:

            Display full size

            FIGURE 1 QWERTY keyboard.

            Display full size

            FIGURE 2 Square Alphabetic keyboard.

            Display full size

            FIGURE 3 Genetic keyboard.

            •

            QWERTY (Figure 1): Although it is the most famous keyboard layout, as underscored by (Zhai et al., 2000), it was designed to be used with two hands and it loses all its accuracy when it is used with only “one finger.” The positive side of this keyboard is that it is already known by a great number of people familiar with computers, which means that they do not need a learning period. On the contrary, this keyboard is unsuitable for nonexpert typing users.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 1 QWERTY keyboard.
            •

            Square Alphabetic: On this keyboard, the position of the keys follows the alphabetical order as shown in Figure 2. This keyboard is supposed to be the “easiest” in the sense that each person who knows the alphabet will be able to use it without a learning process.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 2 Square Alphabetic keyboard.
            •

            Genetic: Based on the idea of Brewbaker (2008), we have used a genetic algorithm to generate a new keyboard layout to improve the efficiency of traditional keyboards. Using Don Quixote as a reference text for the Spanish language, our algorithm positions the keys so that the most used letters appear in the center of the keyboard. The result is shown in Figure 3.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 3 Genetic keyboard.

            In our application, the users move over these three keyboard layouts using the arrows of the remote control to go from one letter to another and the “OK” button to validate the letter. As we can see in Figures 1, 2, and 3, all the keyboards contain the backspace key “←” and two space keys.

            It is important to take into account that each time a user would like to write something, he or she needs to locate the desired key on the keyboard, move from the current position to go to the desired key, and then press the OK button. All these actions condition the entry speed that is measured in the experiments. To ease this process, we have included the following mechanisms:

            Display full size

            FIGURE 4 Keyboard's suggestion system puts a green background to the most likely following letters (color figure available online).

            •

            To move from one key to another, the user can press arrow buttons as many times as necessary, or if the desired letter is on the same line or column, the user can maintain the button pressed.

            •

            The borders are connected as in a ball, so the user can go from the top part to the bottom by pressing the up arrow and vice versa, and the user can go from the left part to the right by using the left arrow and vice versa.

            •

            To help the users, we have implemented a suggestion system inspired by the MacKenzie et al. (2001) “letterwise” disambiguation method. Based on what a user writes, the system changes the color of the six most likely letters following what is already written. To provide these recommendations, the system loads a dictionary of the Spanish language (RAE, 2009), and each time a user adds a letter to a word, the system searches for all the words containing the string the user has written. With this list of words, the system computes the most frequent letters after the current string and displays the six most probable with a green background (Figure 4).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 4 Keyboard's suggestion system puts a green background to the most likely following letters (color figure available online).
            •

            When users perform a mistake, the text appears in red and a beep sounds at each incorrect letter written. This audio feedback is specially interesting for older users as stated by Jacko et al. (2005).

            Multitap method

            The fourth evaluated method is the well-known multitap method. Mainly used with mobile phones, this method uses the number keys to write text (Figure 5). As these keys are available in almost every remote control, it is possible to use this mechanism for IDTV systems.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 5 Numeric keys of a television remote control (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 5 Numeric keys of a television remote control (color figure available online).

            This text introduction method is extremely popular among young users who are part of the so-called mobile phone generation. Within a few years the number of expert users of this method will be huge, and they will not need a learning phase to use applications based on this method. This situation combined with the fact that previous works show that it is more efficient than virtual keyboards in IDTV environments (Iatrino & Modeo, 2006) are the reasons why we have considered this method for the evaluation.

            In the application we have developed to carry out the experiments, the keys have been placed in accordance with the European standard ETSI ES 202 130 V2.1.2 (2007-09). An example of the interface is shown in Figure 6. The number 1 key is used to delete and the number 0 for the space. To assist users when they press the same key several times, the current letter is shown as in the top part of Figure 6.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 6 Implementation of the multitap method in our application (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 6 Implementation of the multitap method in our application (color figure available online).

            Regarding the entry speed, it is important to consider that it is conditioned by the time a user needs to identify the key in the remote control, the time to get to the desired letter in the key, and the time to wait for the cursor to move to the next position.

            Theoretical analysis

            Before proceeding with the evaluation of the aforementioned methods with real users, we carried out a theoretical analysis of their performance. For this purpose, we developed a program to calculate the minimum number of keystrokes for each text input method.

            The description of this program follows. For virtual keyboards the program starts in the center of the keyboard and then computes the number of movements from its current position to the next position following the shortest path. For Multitap, the program only computes the number of keystrokes needed to write a text. The program does not perform any error, so it always computes the minimum number of keystrokes needed to write a text.

            To compare the results for each of the methods, we used Don Quixote as a reference text, as it is very representative of the Spanish language.

            The results of this analysis follow:

            •

            QWERTY: 2.26 keystrokes per letter

            •

            Square Alphabetic: 1.92 keystrokes per letter (15% faster than QWERTY)

            •

            Genetic: 1.24 keystrokes per letter (45% faster than QWERTY)

            •

            Multitap: 1.58 keystrokes per letter (30% faster than QWERTY)

            The conclusion is that, in theory, the best method is the Genetic followed by the multitap and the Square Alphabetic. The QWERTY keyboard layout is the worst. Nevertheless, it is important to take into account that these results do not consider some characteristics of real users, which may be important, such as age, experience, possible mistakes performed while writing, and so on.

            2.3. Analysis Process

            To be able to compare the data obtained in the experiment for each of the users, we provide them the texts to write instead of letting them write at will. For this purpose, we created a corpus with representative sentences of the language used in the experiment (Spanish). The corpus has a total of 25 short sentences like “la mayoria controla su uso” or “el primer kilometro de exceso” gathered from Internet newspapers covering various topics (Spanish tildes have been removed to simplify the evaluation). The sentences have an average of five words, and for each session we choose five random sentences.

            Next, to avoid a “learning effect” during a session, we used a counterbalancing technique as proposed by Mackenzie and Tanaka-Ishii (2007b). According to the authors, when participants have to use various methods to perform the same task, an improvement may occur just because of practice. Thus, counterbalancing, by changing the order of use of the different methods, permits to neutralize this effect. In our case, participants were divided into four groups, each one starting with a specific method:

            •

            QWERTY – Square Alphabetic – Genetic – Multitap

            •

            Multitap – QWERTY – Square Alphabetic – Genetic

            •

            Genetic – Multitap – QWERTY – Square Alphabetic

            •

            Square Alphabetic – Genetic – Multitap – QWERTY

            Finally, to track the progression of the participants, they have to complete five sessions. By doing this, we can control the time a user needs to use an input method efficiently, which is very important because a fast method that requires a long learning period may be rejected by users.

            During each session, they have to introduce five sentences of the corpus (never the same) using a Flash application created ad hoc (Figure 7). When the application starts, it selects the first input method of the group of the user and displays one of the five sentences. When the participant has entered the five sentences, a questionnaire is displayed so the user has to answer the three questions. The whole process is repeated four times, so each time a different text input method is used.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 7 Screenshot of the test application.

            Display full size

            FIGURE 7 Screenshot of the test application.

            2.4. Testbed Designed

            During the experiment, each participant was left alone in a room to avoid distractions. To create the most realistic situation possible, each user sat as if he or she was in his or her own living room as shown in Figure 8. An armchair was placed in front of a 32-in. LCD television with the dimensions 814 × 599 mm, placed on top of a table of a height of around 1 m. According to the recommendations of the manufacturer of the television, the armchair was placed at a distance of 2 m (the optimal distance varies from 1.5 to 3 m for this type of display).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 8 Experience environment (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 8 Experience environment (color figure available online).

            We used a conventional television remote control with the numeric keys on the top and the OK and cursor keys on the center. This decision was based on the fact that the vast majority of the televisions and set-top-boxes include regular remote controls with these basic characteristics (without display, touch screen, or similar advanced features). Moreover, several experiments were carried out with remote controls with the numeric, OK, and cursor keys in different positions, without any significant difference in performance.

            2.5. User Data Gathering

            To gather the data for the evaluation, the application was designed to generate an XML log file. An example is shown in Figure 9.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 9 Extract of a user trace (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 9 Extract of a user trace (color figure available online).

            The XML log file contains general information about the user, data of the events occurred during the sessions, and the answers given to the questions performed. Each keystroke is stored as an “event” element that includes three other elements: “time,” “type,” and “value.” The type “arrowstroke” refers to an arrow key that was pressed, and the type “keystroke” to the “OK” key or to a number key (in the case of the multitap method). The type “question” corresponds to questions. The elements “time” and “value” allow us to know the value of the event (e.g., the key pressed or the value of the answer) and the time when it occurred. As we can see in Figure 9, the first event is of type “starphrase,” which identifies the sentence to be written and the text input method.

            3. RESULTS

            3.1. Schedule of the Experiment

            Each of the users had to perform the tests during five sessions on consecutive days. If for some reason this was impossible, we made sure that there were no more than 2 days between each session to guarantee the learning process.

            During the first session, each user had to fill in a questionnaire allowing us to know his or her profession, level and type of studies, habits of using television, mobile phone and computer, and whether they were left or right handed (Figure 10).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 10 Extract of the initial questionnaire.

            Display full size

            FIGURE 10 Extract of the initial questionnaire.

            Once the questionnaire had been completed, we explained to each user the process of the session and the application they had to use. The real goal of the experiment was not divulged and the presentation was strictly the same for each candidate. After this, we gave the user a list of the five sentences he or she had to write. After 2 min the user was left alone to perform the experiment with no time limit.

            In all of the sessions, users had to complete a final questionnaire allowing us to have some feedback regarding the experiment. They had to provide comments about each method (how they were feeling, if they had the impression they were improving, etc.) and rate the following parameters from 1 to 5: ease of use, entry speed, and global satisfaction.

            3.2. Description of the Population

            The experiment was performed with 50 users, aged 20 to 65. Although we initially expect gender not to influence the results, one of the goals of the evaluation is to determine whether this is true or not. Finally, five users are left-handed and the rest are right-handed.

            Users have been classified into three groups depending on their age, as shown in Figure 11. There are 21 users in the “mobile phone” generation, younger than 30, 18 users in the “computer” generation aged 31 to 45, and 11 users older than 45. The results obtained with the oldest users can be very important because, as stated by Taveira and Choi (2009), changes in perceptual and motor skill capabilities that accompany the aging process bring important implications for the design of human–computer interfaces.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 11 Classification of users per age and experience (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 11 Classification of users per age and experience (color figure available online).

            Using the information provided in the questionnaire of the first session, users have been classified into two groups: expert and nonexpert, with the results shown in Figure 11. Initially, differences are expected between these groups of users due to their habits. The figure shows that we do not have expert users older than age 45. This is because it is very difficult to find users with this profile, but nevertheless, this also reflects our social environment.

            3.3. Results

            Writing speed

            The average writing speed in words per minute for each method and session is shown in Figure 12. At first sight, the results show that in terms of writing speed the fastest text input method is the multitap, whereas the slowest is the QWERTY keyboard layout. Table 1 compares the speed between Sessions 1 and 5 for each method but showing the contrasting speeds between expert and nonexpert users.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 12 Average writing speed per session and method (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 12 Average writing speed per session and method (color figure available online).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 1: Average Writing Speed in Sessions 1 and 5 per Method and User Profile (Words per Minute)

            CSVDisplay Table

            No differences were found between male and female users, nor between left and right-handed users. Nevertheless, Table 1 shows that there is a clear difference between expert and non-expert users. Thus, for a more detailed analysis text entry speeds between the first and last sessions were analyzed using an analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the results obtained in Table 2.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 2: Analysis of Variance for Global, Nonexpert, and Expert Speeds

            CSVDisplay Table

            During the first session, the effect size (η2) is higher for nonexpert users (η2 = 0.483, which corresponds to about 50% of the variation) than for expert users (η2 = 0.410, which is 41% of the variation). This indicates that the method used for the first time has more influence on nonexpert users than on expert users. For the last session, the effect size for all the users has increased (η2 = 0.561, which means that more than 56% of the variation of the speed is caused by the method used). This is mainly caused by the high increase of the expert users effect size (η2 = 0.622), whereas nonexpert effect size remains stable (η2 = 0.491). This indicates that expert users are able to greatly improve their performance with certain methods as time passes, whereas the improvement of performance for nonexpert users is more balanced.

            Pairwise comparisons show significant differences between the methods in all the sessions. In general, multitap is the fastest method with a statistically significant difference with the rest of the methods, coinciding with the results of Iatrino and Modeo (2006) but contradicting the results of Geleijnse et al. (2009). In contrast, QWERTY is the slowest with a statistically significant difference especially for expert users. Also, the Genetic is clearly the best of the virtual keyboard layouts. These results coincide to some extent with those obtained from the theoretical analysis, with QWERTY and Square Alphabetic as the worst methods and Genetic and multitap as the best methods. Nevertheless, contrasting with the theoretical analysis, the best performance is obtained with the multitap method and not with the Genetic. Performance of the Square Alphabetic method shows that, like for mobile devices (Zhai et al., 2002), the alphabetic order does not help users in terms of writing speed.

            To check the influence of age on writing speed, we have performed a correlation analysis. As we can see in Table 3 and Figures 13 and 14, the correlation between the age of nonexpert users and their writing speed is very high (abs( r ) > .714) and significant (p < .01), which clearly indicates that age is a major factor in the entry speed and should be taken into account in theoretical studies, especially when users may be considered nonexperts. The age of expert users is also correlated with the entry speed, but to a lesser extent (.411 < abs( r ) < .573).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 3: Correlations Between the Age of the Users and the Entry Speed

            CSVDisplay Table

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 13 Overlay scatter diagram of writing speed per method and age during Session 1 (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 13 Overlay scatter diagram of writing speed per method and age during Session 1 (color figure available online).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 14 Overlay scatter diagram of writing speed per method and age during Session 5 (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 14 Overlay scatter diagram of writing speed per method and age during Session 5 (color figure available online).

            These results show that the age of target users is an important factor that needs to be taken into account when designing a text entry method. The results coincide with the habits expressed by the users in the initial tests. If we perform a correlation analysis with the age and the habits reported by the users we see a clear dependence. For example, the correlation between age and the usage of Short Message Service (r = –0.335, p < .05) reveal that the younger the user is the higher the number of messages he or she sends. Figures 13 and 14 show that the users of the “mobile phone” generation obtain the highest writing speeds with the multitap method. This also happens with this generation and the “computer” generation, and the usage of computers (r = –.681, p < .001). Figures 13 and 14 show that these users obtain similar writing speeds with virtual keyboard layouts, higher than the speeds obtained by older users. Furthermore, as we can see in Table 3, the differences between nonexpert and expert users are important and a student's T test shows they are also significant (p < .001). Thus, age in a nonexpert user is a good indicator for predicting performance.

            Error rates

            The data gathered during the experiment allow us to analyze error rates for each method. Due to the learning period planned, our analysis focuses only on last session error rates. Although no differences were found between male and female users, or between left- and right-handed users, Table 4 shows that there are some differences depending on the method and the group of users.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 4: Error Rates of the Last Session for Each Group and Each Method

            CSVDisplay Table

            An ANOVA analysis of error rates shows that there is a statistically significant difference between error rates in the last session (Table 5). Pairwise comparisons indicate that the main difference occurs between the multitap method and virtual keyboards. These results are not really surprising because, compared with virtual keyboards, multitap is very error prone and, consequently, causes a higher number of errors. For example, inserting an incorrect letter may be caused either because an incorrect key was pressed or because an incorrect letter was selected when the keyboard timer expired.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 5: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) of the Last Session Error Rates

            CSVDisplay Table

            In the case of virtual keyboards, the most frequent error is the omission of a letter or the insertion of an incorrect letter, forcing users to delete what they have written. In some cases, users are not aware of the mistake although the text appears in red and a beep sounds at each incorrect letter written. Such situations have greatly increased the error rate of some users, as they had to delete a lot of characters.

            If we consider the age of the participants, the results of correlation analyses shown in Table 6 indicate that, in general, age influences error rates for the QWERTY and Genetic keyboards. Nevertheless, it should be noted that correlations are not very strong. In the case of nonexpert users, the analysis shows that there is a correlation between age and multitap and the Genetic error rates, indicating that error rates increase with age for these methods. In contrast, the analysis for expert users did not show any correlation between age and error rates.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 6: Correlations Between the Age of the Users and Error Rates

            CSVDisplay Table

            Apart from not finding strong correlations between age and error rates, we did not find strong correlations between the error rate and the habits reported by the users. The only significant correlations found between these habits and error rates were for the QWERTY (r = –.390, p < .01) and the Genetic (r = –.481, p = .001) methods, meaning that expert users perform fewer errors but only with these methods. The fact that expert and nonexpert users show the same performance for the rest of the methods seems to be due to the care taken by nonexpert users in contrast with the self-confidence of expert users.

            Users’ point of view

            As we have said previously, each user had to fill in a final questionnaire in every session providing some feedback. These questionnaires allow us to provide some interesting remarks:

            •

            In a lot of cases, frequent users of computers said that they felt more comfortable with QWERTY although the data showed that they were much better with other methods. This obviously reflects that the subjective opinion of some users is totally conditioned a proiri by their personal experience.

            •

            The order of the letters in the Square Alphabetic keyboard was an important help for users. As commented by them, the fact that the order of the letters was very familiar prevented them from getting lost or, if they did get lost, helped them to find the letters again. In contrast, the order of the letters in the Genetic keyboard was a bit confusing. For this keyboard, the suggestion mechanism was very helpful, but users felt lost when they had to enter a new word and no suggestions were available for the first letter. However, as sessions passed by, subjects admitted that the Genetic keyboard was easier and faster than the Square Alphabetic.

            •

            The suggestion system had benefits, but it also caused some problems. On one hand, the subjects really appreciated the suggestions offered by this system, because it helped them to locate the keys very easily. On the other hand, the subjects focused too much on the recommendations, and this was an inconvenience when the desired letter was not one of the recommended, causing the users a sensation of being lost and some delays.

            •

            The position of the Space and Delete keys in the QWERTY and Square Alphabetic keyboards was reported as problematic for many users. Many participants found that they were losing a lot of time each time they had to insert a space or delete a letter. This problem increased because only a few users used the mechanism available to move from side to side in a “ball” effect. Users could have used this mechanism to save time, but some reported that they realized too late that they could do so.

            •

            Finally, the multitap method can be considered a special case. Indeed, a lot of users found it faster than the other methods, but many other users found it very uncomfortable. The majority of the participants said that, after reading the sentences they had to write, they were only concentrating on the remote control and stopped watching the television. They also said that this method requires intense concentration, which led them to change their position in the armchair (they moved from a relaxed position to a chairlike position). Finally, some users found the numeric keys too small, making writing difficult.

            Apart from these comments, in the questionnaires the participants had to rate the methods in three aspects: ease of use, speed, and global satisfaction. The difference between the average scores for “Ease of Use” is minimal, confirmed with an ANOVA. It seems that users have taken a neutral position with average scores ranging between 2.5 and 3, no matter their profile.

            As we can see in Figure 15, the mean scores for “Entry Speed” seem to form two different groups. In general, users think that they improve the speed with the multitap and the Genetic methods as sessions pass but that they remain constant or get slower with the QWERTY and the Square Alphabetic methods. An ANOVA of the data shows this tendency very clearly for expert users. However, for nonexpert users this is not so clear, indicating that they always have the impression that they improve their speed with time for all the methods.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 15 Mean scores of “Entry Speed” (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 15 Mean scores of “Entry Speed” (color figure available online).

            We found slight correlations between the real entry speeds of the participants and their subjective scores but only for the Genetic (r = .444, p < .001) and multitap (r = .581, p < .001) methods. This correlation does not exist for the QWERTY and Alphabetic methods because users think that they do not improve their performance with these layouts, although they really do, as shown in Figure 12.

            As in the case of “Entry Speed,” the average scores of “Global satisfaction” seem to form two different groups as shown in Figure 16. Satisfaction increases with the multitap and the Genetic methods but remains constant or decreases with the QWERTY and the Square Alphabetic methods. As shown in Table 7, the ANOVA performed shows a significant difference for each user profile. Changes in satisfaction are more method dependent in general for expert users but not for nonexpert users, who always show the same level of satisfaction. Pairwise comparisons confirm these results.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 7: Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) of the Means to the Question “Global Satisfaction”

            CSVDisplay Table

            FIGURE 16 Means of the scores of “Global Satisfaction” (color figure available online).

            Finally, there are no significant differences in the ratings caused by gender and hand-orientation.

            Learning

            The way users learn and improve their writing speed during the experiment has also been analyzed. Figure 17 shows the learning curve for each method for global users. These were computed using the power law of learning (Ritter & Schooler, 2002), and the obtained models are shown in Table 8 and Figure 17.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 17 Writing speed (wpm) learning curve for global users (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 17 Writing speed (wpm) learning curve for global users (color figure available online).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            Table 8: Models of the Changing Rate of Learning per Method for Global Users

            CSVDisplay Table

            R 2 indicates the rate of variance included in the model. In our case, the models for virtual keyboards have a high R 2 value (around 98% of the variance is included in each model). The model for the multitap method has a variance included of only 91.75%. The drop rate on the last two sessions can explain this. The curve of this model closely resembles a saturation curve.

            If we concentrate on nonexpert users, Table 9 and Figure 18 show that the capacity of learning is higher with the multitap and the genetic methods. Also, it is slightly higher with the genetic (0.2083) than with the multitap method (0.2001).

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors

            If we analyze the capacity of learning for expert users, we obtain similar results to those of global users, as shown in Table 10 and Figure 19.

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors

            Table 10: Models of the Changing Rate of Learning per Method for Expert Users

            CSVDisplay Table

            Evaluation of Virtual Keyboards for Interactive Digital Television Applications

            All authors
            Jonathan Perrinet, Xabiel G. Pañeda, Sergio Cabrero, David Melendi, Roberto García & Víctor García
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.555305
            Published online:
            04 March 2011

            FIGURE 19 Writing speed (wpm) learning curve for expert users (color figure available online).

            Display full size

            FIGURE 19 Writing speed (wpm) learning curve for expert users (color figure available online).

            As shown in the previous figures and tables, users are better learners of the Genetic and multitap methods. This explains the aforementioned absence of a correlation between the real entry speeds of the participants and their subjective scores for the QWERTY and Alphabetic methods. Learning speed clearly conditions the subjective impression of the users.

            Finally, there are no significant differences in learning curves caused by gender and hand-orientation.

            4. DISCUSSION

            This article focuses on the way users can interact effectively with IDTV applications for writing text. As remote controls are the main interaction devices in this environment, we compared four different text input methods using a television remote control. Three methods are based on virtual keyboard layouts and one is the popular multitap method.

            The results were obtained by monitoring the activity of real users, and they show that there are significant differences between the evaluated methods regarding the writing speed, the error rate, the ability to learn and improve, the characteristics of the users, and their general satisfaction.

            We have seen that age is a very important aspect to be taken into account, especially for a target audience of nonexpert users, who experience problems with some of the evaluated methods such as multitap. On the other hand, expert users are more flexible and can adapt very easily to any method. Thus, the selection of an input method requires a previous analysis of the target audience. We have also seen that gender and hand-orientation are not relevant.

            Regarding the evaluated methods, the best method is the multitap for users from the mobile generation. For the rest of users, although this is the fastest method, it has the highest error rate, its learning curve resembles a certain saturation, and it is considered very uncomfortable. Thus, the results show that, in general, the Genetic keyboard layout is the best of the four analyzed methods, as users are more comfortable, perform fewer errors, show a good learning curve, and obtain a considerable writing speed. The only problem with this layout is that users are not familiar with it and a short learning period is required. Nevertheless, if IDTV applications start using this layout, the best results possible are obtained. The major problem noted with virtual keyboards is that, in opinion of the users, the Space and Delete keys are misplaced. As we saw during the experiment, almost all the users made some remark about these keys. The solution for dealing with this problem (solution that was proposed by some participants, too) is to assign Space and Delete to two specific buttons of the remote control.

            There are several publications that address text input methods, but almost all of them concentrate on mobile devices. Text input methods have become a new challenge with the arrival of IDTV, and this topic has been studied in only a few publications. Thus, the obtained results are very important not only for the design of new applications in this environment but also for the research of new techniques to introduce text.

            Thanks to the problems identified in this experience, we plan to pursue experimentations in several ways. First, we will follow participants' observations and we will study the addition of shortcut keys for Space and Delete (in the case of the virtual keyboards) and its effects on performance. Second, we would like to add numbers and special characters to the keyboards, which will allow us to experiment the use of such methods in specific contexts like e-commerce or e-government. Depending on the context, users will mainly need to write short sentences (a credit card number, a username, a password, etc.) or long texts (an e-mail, a resumé, etc.). This requires a previous analysis of the types of information used in these contexts as in Orbist et al. (2008), meaning that the experiments can be carried out with specific instead of generic sentences. The experiments will allow us to check the relation between context and performance. Third, we would like to analyze the use of other recommendation systems such as T9, or auto completion mechanisms.

            Finally, an interesting area of research concerns the hardware level (the remote control itself). We would like to study if the model of the remote control can have any influence on the user experience (shape, number, and location of buttons, etc.).

            Square Alphabetic y = 6.5565 × 0.1591, R 2 = .978
            Genetic y = 6.8553 × 0.1922, R 2 = .9932
            Multitap y = 8.0404 × 0.2287, R 2 = .9514

            Notes

            This research has been financed by the network operator Telecable de Asturias S.A.U. and the Spanish National Research Programme within the project FUTURMEDIA (TSI2007-60474).
